components.name: 1-Introduction
components.text:
Welcome to the Divorce Flow A2J Guided Interview. This interview will walk you through a series of questions that should take you between ___ and ___ minutes to complete. In the end, you'll be provided with a Personalized Plan that will include the resources you need to learn more about the next steps in the divorce process and the paperwork you will need to start the process.

To learn more about this project, go here

components.name: 2-Choose issue
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% which of the following best describes your situation? You can always come back later and make a different selection.

fields.label: The judge made a final decision, but I am not happy with it.
The final decision happened but I want to change something.
The final decision happened, but I want the other side to follow the order.

components.name: 3-Not happy with final decision
components.text:
You said that the judge made a final decision, but you're not happy with it.


You have some options depending on how long ago the final decision was made and the issues you are unhappy about.

In family law cases there may be options to deal with mistakes or changes by filing documents in the Superior Court and not filing an appear in the Supreme Court. You can learn more about that here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 1-Divorce already granted?
components.text: Is your issue about a divorce that has already been granted?
components.learn: How do I know if a divorce has already been granted?
components.help: If you don't know if a final divorce decree has been granted, you can search the records of the clerk of the county court in the county that the divorce was filed in. Generally that is the county where one or both of the parties lives.

components.name: 4-Not happy with final decision 2
components.text: You have two potential options if you are not happy with the final decision that the judge made. You can file a motion for reconsideration or file a motion to modify. Click the one you would like to learn more about.

components.name: 5-Motion for reconsideration
components.text: You said you are interested in learning more about a motion for reconsideration. You may be able to file a motion for reconsideration if it is within 10 days from the date shown in the certificate below the judge's signature and for a specific reason allowed under the court rules. Learn more about the reasons and find the forms here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 6-Motion to modify
components.text: You said you are interested in the motion to modify. At the end of this interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 7-Want to change something
components.text: You said the final decision already happened, but you wan to change something. What do you want to change?

buttons.label: The parenting plan or child support order

components.name: 4- Alaska or Hawaii
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% do you live in Alaska or Hawaii?

components.name: 8-Property or Debt division change
components.text: It is difficult to change a property and debt division after a final judgment because the things may have been sold, assets transferred, or otherwise disposed of. Learn more and find the form to request to modify a property allocation at: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/property.htm#change.

components.name: 9-Change parenting plan or child support
components.text: You said that you want to learn more about modifying a parenting plan or a child support order. When you have completed the interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 10-Other side follow order
components.text:
You said that the final decision happened, but you want the other side to follow the order.


%%[Want other side to follow order extra text TE]%%

components.name: 1-End marriage
components.text: Do you want to end your marriage?

components.name: 2-End marriage yes
components.text: Are you legally married to the person you want to divorce?

components.name: 4-Legally married no Alaska
components.text: There is no common law marriage in Alaska. In order to file for divorce, you must be legally married first.

components.name: 5-Legally married no Hawaii
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must be legally married and have lived in Hawaii for 6 months, and on the same island for 3 months. Since you are not legally married, you are not eligible to file for divorce.

components.name: 7-Wife pregnant Hawaii?
components.text: Is the wife currently pregnant or are there any children born during the marriage who are not related to the husband?

buttons.label: Yes
buttons.destination: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii

components.name: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii
components.text:
If the wife is pregnant, you can file for divorce but a judge will not grant the divorce until the child is born. If the child is the biological child of both spouses, orders will be granted regarding that child in the divorce case. If the child is born out of wedlock, the judge will only grant the divorce if the parties submit either a paternity judgment or an affidavit from both spouses and the biological father of the child, AND a Supplemental Order regarding the Child.


Additional information about this will be included in your Personalized Plan at the end of this interview.

components.name: 2a-End marriage no
components.text: Is separation an option?

components.name: 2b - Separation information
components.text: If you or your spouse want to stay married, but the other spouse doesn't, that spouse can file for divorce. The court will grant the divorce as long as 1 spouse wants the marriage to end. If you are interested in marriage counseling or mediation, here are resources (NONE LISTED IN MINDMEISTER)

components.name: 2c - Separation information 2
components.text:
There is a court process that continues your married status but enters a final order that divides marital property and debt. It can also provide a parenting plan and child support order. This process is used by people who want to remain legally married to protect significant religious, financial, social, or legal interests.


You could decide at a later date to file for divorce, which would end the marriage.

A legal separation is not required as a step on the way to getting a divorce. There are no court forms to file for a legal separation so you either need to draft up your own or talk to an attorney.

components.name: 2d - Separation information 3
components.text: You can separate informally without going to court by making your own arrangements with your spouse. However, if one of you decides to not follow the agreed arrangement, you will not have a court order to enforce the agreement. If you are concerned that the other side may not follow the separation agreement, you may want to file a court case. Your options are a legal separation or a divorce.

components.name: 1-Filed?
components.text: Have either of you filed for divorce?

components.name: 3a-Resident of Alaska
components.text: Are either you or your spouse an Alaska resident?

components.name: 3-Resident of Hawaii
components.text: Have you or your spouse lived in Hawaii for at least 6 months?

components.name: 3b-Resident of Alaska yes
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident.


If you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.


If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3c-Resident of Alaska no
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident.


Also, if you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.

If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3d-Resident of Hawaii no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6 months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived in Hawaii for 6 months, you are not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6a-Lived on same island 3 mo no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6 months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived on the same island for 3 months, you're not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6-Lived on same island 3 mo?
components.text: Have you lived on the island you want to file on for at least 3 months?

components.name: Marital Assets and Debts Definition
components.text:
Marital assets refer to property, including house(s), cash, stocks, bonds, cars, pensions, retirement accounts, insurance policies, etc. that were earned or received during the marriage.


Marital debt is money owed that was indebted during the marriage.

components.name: New page 2 2
components.text: My text

components.name: 1-Assets or Debts?
components.text: Do you and your spouse have marital assets or debt?
components.learn: What if my spouse and I don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt?
components.help:
If you and your spouse don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt, the court will decide based on what is "fair and equitable," by looking at many factors.


Usually the court will award each spouse what belonged to them before the marriage, unless the property changed to be considered marital.

%%[Marital asset additional language AK TE]%%

components.name: 2-Temporary order needed?
components.text: Do you need temporary orders in the meantime?
components.learn: What if we are not in agreement on certain key issues?
components.help: If you and your spouse are not in agreement on certain key issues such as custody or financial support, you may file a "Motion and Affidavit for Pre-Decree Relief," which is used to request every type of available relief in a case where a divorce has not yet been granted.

components.name: 3-Yes to Temporary Orders Needed
components.text: You said that you need temporary orders related. When you finish the interview, additional information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 4-Emergency? (Alaska only)
components.text: Is there an emergency requiring a decision to be made ASAP (as soon as possible)?

components.name: 5-Explanation of Uncontested Divorce option
components.text: Based on your answers, uncontested divorce may be an option for you and your spouse. When you finish the interview, more information on uncontested divorce will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 2-Have not filed yet
components.text: You said neither you nor your spouse has filed for divorce yet, but that you wanted additional information. Additional information on filing for divorce will be provided for you in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 3-Don't know if filed

components.name: 4-Stage of case
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%%, you said that you or your spouse has already filed for divorce. What stage of the case are you in?

fields.label: I filed the complaint to start the case.
I received a complaint from the other side
The case has been filed, but I need to judge to decide something temporarily before the final decision.
The case has been filed, but I want to respond to the other side's motion or request.
The case has been filed, but I am waiting for a hearing on a motion or request.
The case has been filed, but I am waiting for trial.
The case has been filed, but I am waiting for the judge's decision.
A final decision has been handed down, but I want to change it.

components.name: 5-Filed complaint, did you serve spouse?
components.text: You said that you filed a complaint to start the case. Have you served your spouse?
components.learn: What is service?
components.help: As part of the divorce, your spouse must be properly given a copy of the divorce forms you filed at court so that they know you are starting the divorce process. This is called "serving your spouse."

components.name: 6-Did not serve spouse
components.text:
Proper service is required at the beginning of every divorce action because:

1. it tells your spouse what is going on, and
2. it gives your spouse a change to respond to the court papers.

components.name: 7-Service explanation continued
components.text: Does your spouse live in the same state as you?

components.name: 8-Spouse in same state yes
components.text: You said your spouse lives in the same state as you. When you finish this interview, I'll include additional information about serving your spouse in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 9-Know where spouse is?
components.text: Do you know where your spouse is?

components.name: 10-Service by mail
components.text: %%[Service by mail wording TE]%%

components.name: 11-Service by publication
components.text: You said you don't know where your spouse is. In this situation you can use Service by Publication or Service by Mail in Lieu of Publication. When you finish this interview, I'll include more information about this in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 12-Other side filed answer?
components.text: Has the other side filed an Answer?
components.learn: What is an Answer?
components.help: An Answer is a written response that your spouse writes and filed with the court, telling the court what they agree or disagree with in the Complaint for Divorce and what they want from the divorce.

components.name: 13-No Answer Filed
components.text: You said your spouse hasn't filed an Answer yet. Has 20 days passed since the other side was served with the complaint?

components.name: 14-20 days hasn't passed.
components.text: You said your spouse hasn't filed an Answer and 20 days has not passed since you served your spouse with the Complaint for Divorce. When you finish this interview, I'll give you more information in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 15-All in agreement?
components.text: Are you and your spouse in agreement about the terms of the divorce (division of marital assets and debts, financial support, etc?)

components.name: 16-Agreement on all issues
components.text:
You said that you and your spouse agree on all the terms/issues in the divorce.

%%[Uncontested divorce info TE]%%

components.name: 17- Agreement on some issues
components.text: Do you feel like you can communicate safely with our spouse about issues involved with the divorce?

components.name: 18-Mediator?
components.text: Have you and your spouse talked with a professional or other third party to help reach an agreement?
components.learn: What are some methods available for reaching an agreement?
components.help: There are many methods available to reach an agreement. Mediation and collaborative divorce are often very useful alternatives to solving marital conflicts.

components.name: 19- Talked to mediator/third party already
components.text: If you are still not able to come to an agreement through mediation or other methods, you may want to consider hiring a private attorney or contacting a legal services organization for further assistance. When you finish the interview, I'll add more information about this to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 20-DV referral
components.text: You have said you don't feel safe discussing the remaining unresolved issues with your spouse. When you are finished with this interview, I will add information to your Personalized Plan with DV specific legal/social services organizations and referrals to attorneys that can represent survivors ((WORDING FROM MINDMEISTER-- NO actual info on referrals/additional info))

components.name: 21- Haven't talked to mediator yet
components.text: It would be a good idea to set up an appointment with a professional mediator who can help you reach an agreement. When you finish this interview, I'll add additional information that will help you find a mediator.

components.name: 22-Don't agree on issues or don't know
components.text: Do you want to try to reach an agreement with the help of a third party?

components.name: 23-Received a complaint from the other side
components.text: You said that you have received a complaint for the other side. Have you filed an Answer to the Complaint within 20 days of being served with it?
components.learn: What is an Answer?
components.help: An Answer is a written response that you write and file with the court stating what you agree and disagree with in the Complaint and what you want from the divorce.

components.name: 24- Already filed answer
components.text: Are you in agreement on all issues?

components.name: 25-In agreement
components.text: You said you were in agreement on all issues. The divorce will likely proceed as an uncontested case, meaning you and your spouse are in agreement on all issues of the divorce. When you finish this interview, I'll add additional information to your Personalized Plan about this.

components.name: 26- Not in agreement
components.text: You said that you and your spouse are not in agreement on all issues. When you are finished with this interview, I will include additional information about professional mediation in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 27-Need temporary orders?
components.text: Do you need temporary orders in the meantime?

components.name: 28-Did not file answer
components.text: If you don't file an answer within 20 days, the other side can ask the court for a default judgment based only on the information provided in the complaint. If the other side hasn't filed for a default judgment, you can file an answer so the judge can consider what you think about the issues raised on the complaint and so you can tell the judge what you want to happen. If the court has already entered a default judgment against you, you can ask for it to be set aside.

components.name: 1-Introduction
components.text:
Welcome to the Divorce Flow A2J Guided Interview. This interview will walk you through a series of questions that should take you between ___ and ___ minutes to complete. In the end, you'll be provided with a Personalized Plan that will include the resources you need to learn more about the next steps in the divorce process and the paperwork you will need to start the process. 

To learn more about this project, go here.

components.name: 2-Introduction 2
components.text:
As you complete this interview you may see words that are underlined like this. You can click those words to get a definition or explanation of that word. You will also see bubbles that appear next to your avatar with the phrase "Learn More". If you want to learn more about that topic, you can click the "Learn More" button and additional information will appear. 


Throughout the interview, you can click the "Back" button at the top of the screen to go back and change your answers. You can also leave and come back later to finish the interview by clicking the "Exit" button in the top right corner of your screen.  

Let's get started.
components.learn: What is a Learn More?
components.help: A Learn More is a way for us to give you additional information about a topic or to explain a question more. A Learn More can be a video, a picture, or just plain text. It can also contain links to additional information on other websites.

components.name: Example of a pop up
components.text: This is an example of a pop up. In legal documents there can be "terms of art" that the court uses or legal terms from the statute that can be difficult to understand. Whenever it is necessary to use those terms, we will try to provide definitions or explanations within these pop ups.

components.name: 3-Name
components.text: Enter your name and chose an avatar that best represents you.
components.learn: Why do I need to chose an avatar?
components.help: We use the avatar to represent you as you move through this interview. You can chose whichever avatar you are most comfortable with representing you.

components.name: 3b-Resident of Alaska yes
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


If you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.


If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3c-Resident of Alaska no

components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?

If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: Marital Assets and Debts Definition
components.text:
Marital assets refer to property, including house(s), cash, stocks, bonds, cars, pensions, retirement accounts, insurance policies, etc. that were earned or received during the marriage. 


Marital debt is money owed that was indebted during the marriage.

components.name: 1-Assets or Debts?
components.text: Do you and your spouse have marital assets or debt?
components.learn: What if my spouse and I don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt?
components.help:
If you and your spouse don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt, the court will decide based on what is "fair and equitable," by looking at many factors. 


Usually the court will award each spouse what belonged to them before the marriage, unless the property changed to be considered marital.

END IF

components.name: 5-Filed complaint, did you serve spouse?
components.text: You said that you filed a complaint to start the case. Have you served your spouse?
components.learn: What is service?
components.help: As part of the divorce, your spouse must be properly given a copy of the divorce forms you filed at court so that they know you are starting the divorce process. This is called "serving your spouse."

components.name: 6-Did not serve spouse
components.text:
Proper service is required at the beginning of every divorce action because:

1. it tells your spouse what is going on, and
2. it gives your spouse a change to respond to the court papers.

components.name: 25-In agreement

components.name: 26- Not in agreement

components.name: 28-Did not file answer
components.text: If you don't file an answer within 20 days, the other side can ask the court for a default judgment based only on the information provided in the complaint. If the other side hasn't filed for a default judgment, you can file an answer so the judge can consider what you think about the issues raised on the complaint and so you can tell the judge what you want to happen. If the court has already entered a default judgment against you, you can ask for it to be set aside.

components.name: 1-Introduction
components.text:
Welcome to the Divorce Flow A2J Guided Interview. This interview will walk you through a series of questions that should take you between ___ and ___ minutes to complete. In the end, you'll be provided with a Personalized Plan that will include the resources you need to learn more about the next steps in the divorce process and the paperwork you will need to start the process.

To learn more about this project, go here.

components.name: 2-Introduction 2
components.text:
As you complete this interview you may see words that are underlined like this. You can click those words to get a definition or explanation of that word. You will also see bubbles that appear next to your avatar with the phrase "Learn More". If you want to learn more about that topic, you can click the "Learn More" button and additional information will appear.


Throughout the interview, you can click the "Back" button at the top of the screen to go back and change your answers. You can also leave and come back later to finish the interview by clicking the "Exit" button in the top right corner of your screen.

Let's get started.
components.learn: What is a Learn More?
components.help: A Learn More is a way for us to give you additional information about a topic or to explain a question more. A Learn More can be a video, a picture, or just plain text. It can also contain links to additional information on other websites.

components.name: Example of a pop up
components.text: This is an example of a pop up. In legal documents there can be "terms of art" that the court uses or legal terms from the statute that can be difficult to understand. Whenever it is necessary to use those terms, we will try to provide definitions or explanations within these pop ups.

components.name: 3-Name
components.text: Enter your name and chose an avatar that best represents you.
components.learn: Why do I need to chose an avatar?
components.help: We use the avatar to represent you as you move through this interview. You can chose whichever avatar you are most comfortable with representing you.

components.name: 3-Not happy with final decision
components.text:
You said that the judge made a final decision, but you're not happy with it.


You have some options depending on how long ago the final decision was made and the issues you are unhappy about.

In family law cases there may be options to deal with mistakes or changes by filing documents in the Superior Court and not filing an appear in the Supreme Court. You can learn more about that here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 1-Divorce already granted?
components.text: Is your issue about a divorce that has already been granted?
components.learn: How do I know if a divorce has already been granted?
components.help: If you don't know if a final divorce decree has been granted, you can search the records of the clerk of the county court in the county that the divorce was filed in. Generally that is the county where one or both of the parties lives.

components.name: 4-Not happy with final decision 2
components.text: You have two potential options if you are not happy with the final decision that the judge made. You can file a motion for reconsideration or file a motion to modify. Click the one you would like to learn more about.

components.name: 5-Motion for reconsideration
components.text: You said you are interested in learning more about a motion for reconsideration. You may be able to file a motion for reconsideration if it is within 10 days from the date shown in the certificate below the judge's signature and for a specific reason allowed under the court rules. Learn more about the reasons and find the forms here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 5-Legally married no Hawaii
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must be legally married and have lived in Hawaii for 6 months, and on the same island for 3 months. Since you are not legally married, you are not eligible to file for divorce.

components.name: 7-Wife pregnant Hawaii?
components.text: Is the wife currently pregnant or are there any children born during the marriage who are not related to the husband?

buttons.label: Yes
buttons.destination: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii

components.name: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii
components.text:
If the wife is pregnant, you can file for divorce but a judge will not grant the divorce until the child is born. If the child is the biological child of both spouses, orders will be granted regarding that child in the divorce case. If the child is born out of wedlock, the judge will only grant the divorce if the parties submit either a paternity judgment or an affidavit from both spouses and the biological father of the child, AND a Supplemental Order regarding the Child.


Additional information about this will be included in your Personalized Plan at the end of this interview.

components.name: 2a-End marriage no
components.text: Is separation an option?

components.name: 2b - Separation information
components.text: If you or your spouse want to stay married, but the other spouse doesn't, that spouse can file for divorce. The court will grant the divorce as long as 1 spouse wants the marriage to end. If you are interested in marriage counseling or mediation, here are resources (NONE LISTED IN MINDMEISTER)

components.name: 2c - Separation information 2
components.text:
There is a court process that continues your married status but enters a final order that divides marital property and debt. It can also provide a parenting plan and child support order. This process is used by people who want to remain legally married to protect significant religious, financial, social, or legal interests.


You could decide at a later date to file for divorce, which would end the marriage.

A legal separation is not required as a step on the way to getting a divorce. There are no court forms to file for a legal separation so you either need to draft up your own or talk to an attorney.

components.name: 2d - Separation information 3
components.text: You can separate informally without going to court by making your own arrangements with your spouse. However, if one of you decides to not follow the agreed arrangement, you will not have a court order to enforce the agreement. If you are concerned that the other side may not follow the separation agreement, you may want to file a court case. Your options are a legal separation or a divorce.

components.name: 28-Did not file answer
components.text: If you don't file an answer within 20 days, the other side can ask the court for a default judgment based only on the information provided in the complaint. If the other side hasn't filed for a default judgment, you can file an answer so the judge can consider what you think about the issues raised on the complaint and so you can tell the judge what you want to happen. If the court has already entered a default judgment against you, you can ask for it to be set aside.

components.name: 1-Introduction
components.text:
Welcome to the Divorce Flow A2J Guided Interview. This interview will walk you through a series of questions that should take you between ___ and ___ minutes to complete. In the end, you'll be provided with a Personalized Plan that will include the resources you need to learn more about the next steps in the divorce process and the paperwork you will need to start the process. 

To learn more about this project, go here.

components.name: 2-Introduction 2
components.text:
As you complete this interview you may see words that are underlined like this. You can click those words to get a definition or explanation of that word. You will also see bubbles that appear next to your avatar with the phrase "Learn More". If you want to learn more about that topic, you can click the "Learn More" button and additional information will appear. 


Throughout the interview, you can click the "Back" button at the top of the screen to go back and change your answers. You can also leave and come back later to finish the interview by clicking the "Exit" button in the top right corner of your screen.  

Let's get started.
components.learn: What is a Learn More?
components.help: A Learn More is a way for us to give you additional information about a topic or to explain a question more. A Learn More can be a video, a picture, or just plain text. It can also contain links to additional information on other websites.

components.name: Example of a pop up
components.text: This is an example of a pop up. In legal documents there can be "terms of art" that the court uses or legal terms from the statute that can be difficult to understand. Whenever it is necessary to use those terms, we will try to provide definitions or explanations within these pop ups.

components.name: 3-Name
components.text: Enter your name and chose an avatar that best represents you.
components.learn: Why do I need to chose an avatar?
components.help: We use the avatar to represent you as you move through this interview. You can chose whichever avatar you are most comfortable with representing you.

components.name: 2-Choose issue
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% which of the following best describes your situation? You can always come back later and make a different selection.

fields.label: The judge made a final decision, but I am not happy with it.
The final decision happened but I want to change something.
The final decision happened, but I want the other side to follow the order.

components.name: 3-Not happy with final decision
components.text:
You said that the judge made a final decision, but you're not happy with it. 


You have some options depending on how long ago the final decision was made and the issues you are unhappy about. 

In family law cases there may be options to deal with mistakes or changes by filing documents in the Superior Court and not filing an appear in the Supreme Court. You can learn more about that here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 1-Divorce already granted?
components.text: Is your issue about a divorce that has already been granted?
components.learn: How do I know if a divorce has already been granted?
components.help: If you don't know if a final divorce decree has been granted, you can search the records of the clerk of the county court in the county that the divorce was filed in. Generally that is the county where one or both of the parties lives.

components.name: 4-Not happy with final decision 2
components.text: You have two potential options if you are not happy with the final decision that the judge made. You can file a motion for reconsideration or file a motion to modify. Click the one you would like to learn more about.

components.name: 5-Motion for reconsideration
components.text: You said you are interested in learning more about a motion for reconsideration. You may be able to file a motion for reconsideration if it is within 10 days from the date shown in the certificate below the judge's signature and for a specific reason allowed under the court rules. Learn more about the reasons and find the forms here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 6-Motion to modify
components.text: You said you are interested in the motion to modify. At the end of this interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 7-Want to change something
components.text: You said the final decision already happened, but you wan to change something. What do you want to change?

buttons.label: The parenting plan or child support order

components.name: 4- Alaska or Hawaii
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% do you live in Alaska or Hawaii?

components.name: 8-Property or Debt division change
components.text: It is difficult to change a property and debt division after a final judgment because the things may have been sold, assets transferred, or otherwise disposed of. Learn more and find the form to request to modify a property allocation at: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/property.htm#change.

components.name: 9-Change parenting plan or child support
components.text: You said that you want to learn more about modifying a parenting plan or a child support order. When you have completed the interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 10-Other side follow order
components.text:
You said that the final decision happened, but you want the other side to follow the order.

components.name: 1-End marriage
components.text: Do you want to end your marriage?

components.name: 2-End marriage yes
components.text: Are you legally married to the person you want to divorce?

components.name: 4-Legally married no Alaska
components.text: There is no common law marriage in Alaska. In order to file for divorce, you must be legally married first.

components.name: 5-Legally married no Hawaii
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must be legally married and have lived in Hawaii for 6 months, and on the same island for 3 months. Since you are not legally married, you are not eligible to file for divorce.

components.name: 7-Wife pregnant Hawaii?
components.text: Is the wife currently pregnant or are there any children born during the marriage who are not related to the husband?

buttons.label: Yes
buttons.destination: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii

components.name: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii
components.text:
If the wife is pregnant, you can file for divorce but a judge will not grant the divorce until the child is born. If the child is the biological child of both spouses, orders will be granted regarding that child in the divorce case. If the child is born out of wedlock, the judge will only grant the divorce if the parties submit either a paternity judgment or an affidavit from both spouses and the biological father of the child, AND a Supplemental Order regarding the Child. 


Additional information about this will be included in your Personalized Plan at the end of this interview.

components.name: 2a-End marriage no
components.text: Is separation an option?

components.name: 2b - Separation information
components.text: If you or your spouse want to stay married, but the other spouse doesn't, that spouse can file for divorce. The court will grant the divorce as long as 1 spouse wants the marriage to end. If you are interested in marriage counseling or mediation, here are resources (NONE LISTED IN MINDMEISTER)

components.name: 2c - Separation information 2
components.text:
There is a court process that continues your married status but enters a final order that divides marital property and debt. It can also provide a parenting plan and child support order. This process is used by people who want to remain legally married to protect significant religious, financial, social, or legal interests. 


You could decide at a later date to file for divorce, which would end the marriage. 

A legal separation is not required as a step on the way to getting a divorce. There are no court forms to file for a legal separation so you either need to draft up your own or talk to an attorney.

components.name: 2d - Separation information 3
components.text: You can separate informally without going to court by making your own arrangements with your spouse. However, if one of you decides to not follow the agreed arrangement, you will not have a court order to enforce the agreement. If you are concerned that the other side may not follow the separation agreement, you may want to file a court case. Your options are a legal separation or a divorce.

components.name: 1-Filed?
components.text: Have either of you filed for divorce?

components.name: 3a-Resident of Alaska
components.text: Are either you or your spouse an Alaska resident?

components.name: 3-Resident of Hawaii
components.text: Have you or your spouse lived in Hawaii for at least 6 months?

components.name: 3b-Resident of Alaska yes
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


If you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.


If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3c-Resident of Alaska no
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


Also, if you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.

If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3d-Resident of Hawaii no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6  months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived in Hawaii for 6 months, you are not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6a-Lived on same island 3 mo no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6 months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived on the same island for 3 months, you're not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6-Lived on same island 3 mo?
components.text: Have you lived on the island you want to file on for at least 3 months?

components.name: Marital Assets and Debts Definition
components.text:
Marital assets refer to property, including house(s), cash, stocks, bonds, cars, pensions, retirement accounts, insurance policies, etc. that were earned or received during the marriage. 


Marital debt is money owed that was indebted during the marriage.

components.name: New page 2 2
components.text: My text

components.name: 1-Assets or Debts?
components.text: Do you and your spouse have marital assets or debt?
components.learn: What if my spouse and I don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt?
components.help:
If you and your spouse don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt, the court will decide based on what is "fair and equitable," by looking at many factors. 


Usually the court will award each spouse what belonged to them before the marriage, unless the property changed to be considered marital.  

%%[Marital asset additional language AK TE]%%

components.learn: What if we are not in agreement on certain key issues?
components.help: If you and your spouse are not in agreement on certain key issues such as custody or financial support, you may file a "Motion and Affidavit for Pre-Decree Relief," which is used to request every type of available relief in a case where a divorce has not yet been granted.

components.name: 1-Introduction
components.text:
Welcome to the Divorce Flow A2J Guided Interview. This interview will walk you through a series of questions that should take you between ___ and ___ minutes to complete. In the end, you'll be provided with a Personalized Plan that will include the resources you need to learn more about the next steps in the divorce process and the paperwork you will need to start the process. 

To learn more about this project, go here.

components.name: 2-Introduction 2
components.text:
As you complete this interview you may see words that are underlined like this. You can click those words to get a definition or explanation of that word. You will also see bubbles that appear next to your avatar with the phrase "Learn More". If you want to learn more about that topic, you can click the "Learn More" button and additional information will appear. 


Throughout the interview, you can click the "Back" button at the top of the screen to go back and change your answers. You can also leave and come back later to finish the interview by clicking the "Exit" button in the top right corner of your screen.  

Let's get started.
components.learn: What is a Learn More?
components.help: A Learn More is a way for us to give you additional information about a topic or to explain a question more. A Learn More can be a video, a picture, or just plain text. It can also contain links to additional information on other websites.

components.name: Example of a pop up
components.text: This is an example of a pop up. In legal documents there can be "terms of art" that the court uses or legal terms from the statute that can be difficult to understand. Whenever it is necessary to use those terms, we will try to provide definitions or explanations within these pop ups.

components.name: 3-Name
components.text: Enter your name and chose an avatar that best represents you.
components.learn: Why do I need to chose an avatar?
components.help: We use the avatar to represent you as you move through this interview. You can chose whichever avatar you are most comfortable with representing you.

components.name: 3-Not happy with final decision
components.text:
You said that the judge made a final decision, but you're not happy with it. 


You have some options depending on how long ago the final decision was made and the issues you are unhappy about. 

In family law cases there may be options to deal with mistakes or changes by filing documents in the Superior Court and not filing an appear in the Supreme Court. You can learn more about that here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 1-Divorce already granted?
components.text: Is your issue about a divorce that has already been granted?
components.learn: How do I know if a divorce has already been granted?
components.help: If you don't know if a final divorce decree has been granted, you can search the records of the clerk of the county court in the county that the divorce was filed in. Generally that is the county where one or both of the parties lives.

components.name: 4-Not happy with final decision 2
components.text: You have two potential options if you are not happy with the final decision that the judge made. You can file a motion for reconsideration or file a motion to modify. Click the one you would like to learn more about.

components.name: 5-Motion for reconsideration
components.text: You said you are interested in learning more about a motion for reconsideration. You may be able to file a motion for reconsideration if it is within 10 days from the date shown in the certificate below the judge's signature and for a specific reason allowed under the court rules. Learn more about the reasons and find the forms here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 6-Motion to modify
components.text: You said you are interested in the motion to modify. At the end of this interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.
components.codeAfter:
IF [Alaskan TF] = true AND [File motion to modify TF] = true
SET [Alaskan motion to modify TF] TO TRUE
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] AND [File motion to modify TF] = true
SET [Hawaiian motion to modify TF] TO TRUE
END IF

components.name: 7-Want to change something
components.text: You said the final decision already happened, but you wan to change something. What do you want to change?

buttons.label: The property or debt division
buttons.name: Change property or debt division TF

buttons.label: The parenting plan or child support order
buttons.name: Change parenting plan or child support TF

components.name: 4- Alaska or Hawaii
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% do you live in Alaska or Hawaii?

components.name: 8-Property or Debt division change
components.text: It is difficult to change a property and debt division after a final judgment because the things may have been sold, assets transferred, or otherwise disposed of. Learn more and find the form to request to modify a property allocation at: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/property.htm#change.

components.name: 9-Change parenting plan or child support
components.text: You said that you want to learn more about modifying a parenting plan or a child support order. When you have completed the interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

END IF

components.name: 1-End marriage
components.text: Do you want to end your marriage?

components.name: 2-End marriage yes
components.text: Are you legally married to the person you want to divorce?

components.name: 4-Legally married no Alaska
components.text: There is no common law marriage in Alaska. In order to file for divorce, you must be legally married first.
components.codeBefore:
IF [Hawaiian TF] = true
GOTO "5-Legally married no Hawaii"
END IF

components.name: 5-Legally married no Hawaii
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must be legally married and have lived in Hawaii for 6 months, and on the same island for 3 months. Since you are not legally married, you are not eligible to file for divorce.

components.name: 7-Wife pregnant Hawaii?
components.text: Is the wife currently pregnant or are there any children born during the marriage who are not related to the husband?

buttons.label: Yes
buttons.destination: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii

components.name: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii
components.text:
If the wife is pregnant, you can file for divorce but a judge will not grant the divorce until the child is born. If the child is the biological child of both spouses, orders will be granted regarding that child in the divorce case. If the child is born out of wedlock, the judge will only grant the divorce if the parties submit either a paternity judgment or an affidavit from both spouses and the biological father of the child, AND a Supplemental Order regarding the Child. 


Additional information about this will be included in your Personalized Plan at the end of this interview.

components.name: 2a-End marriage no
components.text: Is separation an option?

components.name: 2b - Separation information
components.text: If you or your spouse want to stay married, but the other spouse doesn't, that spouse can file for divorce. The court will grant the divorce as long as 1 spouse wants the marriage to end. If you are interested in marriage counseling or mediation, here are resources (NONE LISTED IN MINDMEISTER)

components.name: 2c - Separation information 2
components.text:
There is a court process that continues your married status but enters a final order that divides marital property and debt. It can also provide a parenting plan and child support order. This process is used by people who want to remain legally married to protect significant religious, financial, social, or legal interests. 


You could decide at a later date to file for divorce, which would end the marriage. 

A legal separation is not required as a step on the way to getting a divorce. There are no court forms to file for a legal separation so you either need to draft up your own or talk to an attorney.

components.name: 2d - Separation information 3
components.text: You can separate informally without going to court by making your own arrangements with your spouse. However, if one of you decides to not follow the agreed arrangement, you will not have a court order to enforce the agreement. If you are concerned that the other side may not follow the separation agreement, you may want to file a court case. Your options are a legal separation or a divorce.

components.name: 1-Filed?
components.text: Have either of you filed for divorce?

components.name: 3a-Resident of Alaska
components.text: Are either you or your spouse an Alaska resident?

components.name: 3-Resident of Hawaii
components.text: Have you or your spouse lived in Hawaii for at least 6 months?
components.codeBefore:
IF [Alaskan TF] = True
GOTO "3a-Resident of Alaska"
END IF

components.name: 3b-Resident of Alaska yes
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


If you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.


If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3c-Resident of Alaska no
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


Also, if you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.

If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3d-Resident of Hawaii no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6  months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived in Hawaii for 6 months, you are not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6a-Lived on same island 3 mo no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6 months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived on the same island for 3 months, you're not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6-Lived on same island 3 mo?
components.text: Have you lived on the island you want to file on for at least 3 months?

buttons.label: No
buttons.name: 3 mo on island Hawaii false TF

components.name: Marital Assets and Debts Definition
components.text:
Marital assets refer to property, including house(s), cash, stocks, bonds, cars, pensions, retirement accounts, insurance policies, etc. that were earned or received during the marriage. 


Marital debt is money owed that was indebted during the marriage.

components.name: New page 2 2
components.text: My text

components.name: 1-Assets or Debts?
components.text: Do you and your spouse have marital assets or debt?
components.learn: What if my spouse and I don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt?
components.help:
If you and your spouse don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt, the court will decide based on what is "fair and equitable," by looking at many factors. 


Usually the court will award each spouse what belonged to them before the marriage, unless the property changed to be considered marital.  

%%[Marital asset additional language AK TE]%%
components.codeBefore:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Marital asset additional language AK TE] TO "Learn more about the factors courts consider here: http:\/\/www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/property.htm#1g."
ELSE
SET [Marital asset additonal language AK TE] TO " "
END IF

components.name: 2-Temporary order needed?
components.text: Do you need temporary orders in the meantime?
components.learn: What if we are not in agreement on certain key issues?
components.help: If you and your spouse are not in agreement on certain key issues such as custody or financial support, you may file a "Motion and Affidavit for Pre-Decree Relief," which is used to request every type of available relief in a case where a divorce has not yet been granted.

components.name: 3-Yes to Temporary Orders Needed
components.text: You said that you need temporary orders related. When you finish the interview, additional information will be added to your Personalized Plan.
components.codeAfter:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Need temp order AK TF] TO TRUE
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] = true
SET [Need temp order HI TF] TO TRUE
END IF

components.name: 4-Emergency? (Alaska only)
components.text: Is there an emergency requiring a decision to be made ASAP (as soon as possible)?

components.name: 5-Explanation of Uncontested Divorce option
components.text: Based on your answers, uncontested divorce may be an option for you and your spouse. When you finish the interview, more information on uncontested divorce will be included in your Personalized Plan.
components.codeAfter:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Uncontested divorce option AK TF] TO TRUE
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] = TRUE
SET [Uncontested divorce option HI TF] TO TRUE
END IF

components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% have either you or your spouse filed for divorce?

buttons.label: No. There is no case yet, but I want more information.

components.name: 2-Have not filed yet
components.text: You said neither you nor your spouse has filed for divorce yet, but that you wanted additional information. Additional information on filing for divorce will be provided for you in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 3-Don't know if filed
components.text: You said you aren't sure if you or your spouse has already filed for divorce. Additional information will be provided to you in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 4-Stage of case
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%%, you said that you or your spouse has already filed for divorce. What stage of the case are you in?

fields.label: I filed the complaint to start the case.
fields.name: Stage of case already filed MC
fields.value: I filed complaint to start case

fields.label: I received a complaint from the other side

END IF

components.name: 5-Filed complaint, did you serve spouse?
components.text: You said that you filed a complaint to start the case. Have you served your spouse?
components.learn: What is service?
components.help: As part of the divorce, your spouse must be properly given a copy of the divorce forms you filed at court so that they know you are starting the divorce process. This is called "serving your spouse."

components.name: 6-Did not serve spouse
components.text:
Proper service is required at the beginning of every divorce action because:

1. it tells your spouse what is going on, and
2. it gives your spouse a change to respond to the court papers.

components.name: 7-Service explanation continued
components.text: Does your spouse live in the same state as you?

components.name: 8-Spouse in same state yes
components.text: You said your spouse lives in the same state as you. When you finish this interview, I'll include additional information about serving your spouse in your Personalized Plan.
components.codeAfter: SET [Personal service explanation needed TF] TO TRUE

components.name: 9-Know where spouse is?
components.text: Do you know where your spouse is?

components.name: 10-Service by mail
components.text: %%[Service by mail wording TE]%%
components.codeBefore:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Service by mail wording TE] TO "When you and your spouse live in different states you can serve them by mail."
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] = TRUE
SET [Service by mail wording TE] TO "When you and your spouse live in different states or on different islands, you can serve them by mail."
END IF

components.name: 11-Service by publication
components.text: You said you don't know where your spouse is. In this situation you can use Service by Publication or Service by Mail in Lieu of Publication. When you finish this interview, I'll include more information about this in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 12-Other side filed answer?
components.text: Has the other side filed an Answer?
components.learn: What is an Answer?
components.help: An Answer is a written response that your spouse writes and filed with the court, telling the court what they agree or disagree with in the Complaint for Divorce and what they want from the divorce.

components.name: 13-No Answer Filed
components.text: You said your spouse hasn't filed an Answer yet. Has 20 days passed since the other side was served with the complaint?

components.name: 14-20 days hasn't passed.
components.text: You said your spouse hasn't filed an Answer and 20 days has not passed since you served your spouse with the Complaint for Divorce. When you finish this interview, I'll give you more information in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 15-All in agreement?
components.text: Are you and your spouse in agreement about the terms of the divorce (division of marital assets and debts, financial support, etc?)

components.name: 16-Agreement on all issues
components.text:
You said that you and your spouse agree on all the terms/issues in the divorce. 

%%[Uncontested divorce info TE]%%
components.codeBefore:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Uncontested divorce info TE] TO "If both spouses agree on all issues (ending the marriage, property and debt division, parenting plan, and income for child support calculations), then there is a short track process called a dissolution or uncontested divorce. There are 2 options for forms and each requires both spouses to sign the forms together. Learn more about uncontested cases at: http:\/\/www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcuncontested.htm."
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] = TRUE
SET [Uncontested divorce info TE] TO "An unconteted divorce means that both spouses agree about all issues. You can get an uncontested divorce if your spouse signs the divorce papers and agrees to the things you ask for in the divorce or if your spouse does not respond after you have a set of forms served on them."
END IF

components.name: 17- Agreement on some issues
components.text: Do you feel like you can communicate safely with our spouse about issues involved with the divorce?

components.name: 18-Mediator?
components.text: Have you and your spouse talked with a professional or other third party to help reach an agreement?
components.learn: What are some methods available for reaching an agreement?
components.help: There are many methods available to reach an agreement. Mediation and collaborative divorce are often very useful alternatives to solving marital conflicts.

components.name: 19- Talked to mediator/third party already
components.text: If you are still not able to come to an agreement through mediation or other methods, you may want to consider hiring a private attorney or contacting a legal services organization for further assistance. When you finish the interview, I'll add more information about this to your Personalized Plan.
components.codeAfter:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Mediator failed AK TF] TO TRUE
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] = TRUE
SET [Mediator failed HI TF] TO TRUE
END IF

components.name: 20-DV referral
components.text: You have said you don't feel safe discussing the remaining unresolved issues with your spouse. When you are finished with this interview, I will add information to your Personalized Plan with DV specific legal/social services organizations and referrals to attorneys that can represent survivors ((WORDING FROM MINDMEISTER-- NO actual info on referrals/additional info))

components.name: 21- Haven't talked to mediator yet
components.text: It would be a good idea to set up an appointment with a professional mediator who can help you reach an agreement. When you finish this interview, I'll add additional information that will help you find a mediator.

components.name: 22-Don't agree on issues or don't know
components.text: Do you want to try to reach an agreement with the help of a third party?

components.name: 23-Received a complaint from the other side
components.text: You said that you have received a complaint for the other side. Have you filed an Answer to the Complaint within 20 days of being served with it?
components.learn: What is an Answer?
components.help: An Answer is a written response that you write and file with the court stating what you agree and disagree with in the Complaint and what you want from the divorce.

components.name: 24- Already filed answer
components.text: Are you in agreement on all issues?

components.name: 25-In agreement
components.text: You said you were in agreement on all issues. The divorce will likely proceed as an uncontested case, meaning you and your spouse are in agreement on all issues of the divorce.  When you finish this interview, I'll add additional information to your Personalized Plan about this.

components.name: 26- Not in agreement
components.text: You said that you and your spouse are not in agreement on all issues. When you are finished with this interview, I will include additional information about professional mediation in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 27-Need temporary orders?
components.text: Do you need temporary orders in the meantime?

components.name: 28-Did not file answer
components.text: If you don't file an answer within 20 days, the other side can ask the court for a default judgment based only on the information provided in the complaint. If the other side hasn't filed for a default judgment, you can file an answer so the judge can consider what you think about the issues raised on the complaint and so you can tell the judge what you want to happen. If the court has already entered a default judgment against you, you can ask for it to be set aside.
components.codeAfter:
IF [Alaskan TF] = TRUE
SET [Did not file answer AK TF] TO TRUE
END IF


IF [Hawaiian TF] = TRUE
SET [Did not file answer HI TF] TO TRUE
END IF

components.help: If you don't know if a final divorce decree has been granted, you can search the records of the clerk of the county court in the county that the divorce was filed in. Generally that is the county where one or both of the parties lives.

components.name: 4-Not happy with final decision 2
components.text: You have two potential options if you are not happy with the final decision that the judge made. You can file a motion for reconsideration or file a motion to modify. Click the one you would like to learn more about.

components.name: 5-Motion for reconsideration
components.text: You said you are interested in learning more about a motion for reconsideration. You may be able to file a motion for reconsideration if it is within 10 days from the date shown in the certificate below the judge's signature and for a specific reason allowed under the court rules. Learn more about the reasons and find the forms here: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/after-judgment.htm#reconsider.

components.name: 6-Motion to modify
components.text: You said you are interested in the motion to modify. At the end of this interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 7-Want to change something
components.text: You said the final decision already happened, but you wan to change something. What do you want to change?

buttons.label: The property or debt division
buttons.name: Change property or debt division TF

buttons.label: The parenting plan or child support order
buttons.name: Change parenting plan or child support TF

components.name: 4- Alaska or Hawaii
components.text: %%[Client first name TE]%% do you live in Alaska or Hawaii?

components.name: 8-Property or Debt division change
components.text: It is difficult to change a property and debt division after a final judgment because the things may have been sold, assets transferred, or otherwise disposed of. Learn more and find the form to request to modify a property allocation at: http://courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/property.htm#change.

components.name: 9-Change parenting plan or child support
components.text: You said that you want to learn more about modifying a parenting plan or a child support order. When you have completed the interview, this information will be added to your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 10-Other side follow order
components.text:
You said that the final decision happened, but you want the other side to follow the order. 


%%[Want other side to follow order extra text TE]%%

components.name: 1-End marriage
components.text: Do you want to end your marriage?

components.name: 2-End marriage yes
components.text: Are you legally married to the person you want to divorce?

components.name: 4-Legally married no Alaska
components.text: There is no common law marriage in Alaska. In order to file for divorce, you must be legally married first.

components.name: 5-Legally married no Hawaii
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must be legally married and have lived in Hawaii for 6 months, and on the same island for 3 months. Since you are not legally married, you are not eligible to file for divorce.

components.name: 7-Wife pregnant Hawaii?
components.text: Is the wife currently pregnant or are there any children born during the marriage who are not related to the husband?

buttons.label: Yes
buttons.destination: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii

components.name: 8-Pregnant or Children Not of Marriage yes Hawaii
components.text:
If the wife is pregnant, you can file for divorce but a judge will not grant the divorce until the child is born. If the child is the biological child of both spouses, orders will be granted regarding that child in the divorce case. If the child is born out of wedlock, the judge will only grant the divorce if the parties submit either a paternity judgment or an affidavit from both spouses and the biological father of the child, AND a Supplemental Order regarding the Child. 


Additional information about this will be included in your Personalized Plan at the end of this interview.

components.name: 2a-End marriage no
components.text: Is separation an option?

components.name: 2b - Separation information
components.text: If you or your spouse want to stay married, but the other spouse doesn't, that spouse can file for divorce. The court will grant the divorce as long as 1 spouse wants the marriage to end. If you are interested in marriage counseling or mediation, here are resources (NONE LISTED IN MINDMEISTER)

components.name: 2c - Separation information 2
components.text:
There is a court process that continues your married status but enters a final order that divides marital property and debt. It can also provide a parenting plan and child support order. This process is used by people who want to remain legally married to protect significant religious, financial, social, or legal interests. 


You could decide at a later date to file for divorce, which would end the marriage. 

A legal separation is not required as a step on the way to getting a divorce. There are no court forms to file for a legal separation so you either need to draft up your own or talk to an attorney.

components.name: 2d - Separation information 3
components.text: You can separate informally without going to court by making your own arrangements with your spouse. However, if one of you decides to not follow the agreed arrangement, you will not have a court order to enforce the agreement. If you are concerned that the other side may not follow the separation agreement, you may want to file a court case. Your options are a legal separation or a divorce.

components.name: 1-Filed?
components.text: Have either of you filed for divorce?

components.name: 3a-Resident of Alaska
components.text: Are either you or your spouse an Alaska resident?

components.name: 3-Resident of Hawaii
components.text: Have you or your spouse lived in Hawaii for at least 6 months?

components.name: 3b-Resident of Alaska yes
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


If you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.


If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3c-Resident of Alaska no
components.text:
Either you or your spouse may file to end your marriage in Alaska as long as the filing spouse is a resident of the state. Generally, you are an Alaska resident for the purposes of filing for divorce or dissolution if you are in Alaska when you file and intend to stay as a resident. 


Also, if you don't live in Alaska and were married outside of Alaska, but your spouse is an Alaska resident, you can file in Alaska.
components.learn: What if I want to learn more about Alaska's residency requirements?  What if my spouse or I are in the military?
components.help:
You can learn more about Alaska's residency requirements here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#residency.

If you are involved with the military, there are different residency requirements. Learn more about them here: http://www.courts.alaska.gov/shc/family/shcstart.htm#military.

components.name: 3d-Resident of Hawaii no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6  months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived in Hawaii for 6 months, you are not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 6a-Lived on same island 3 mo no
components.text: In order to get divorced in Hawaii, you must have lived in Hawaii for 6 months and on the same island for 3 months. Since you haven't yet lived on the same island for 3 months, you're not eligible to file for divorce at this time. When you finish this interview, more information will be included in your Personalized Plan.

buttons.label: No

components.name: Marital Assets and Debts Definition
components.text:
Marital assets refer to property, including house(s), cash, stocks, bonds, cars, pensions, retirement accounts, insurance policies, etc. that were earned or received during the marriage. 


Marital debt is money owed that was indebted during the marriage.

components.name: New page 2 2
components.text: My text

components.name: 1-Assets or Debts?
components.text: Do you and your spouse have marital assets or debt?
components.learn: What if my spouse and I don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt?
components.help:
If you and your spouse don't agree on how to divide the marital assets and debt, the court will decide based on what is "fair and equitable," by looking at many factors. 


Usually the court will award each spouse what belonged to them before the marriage, unless the property changed to be considered marital.  

%%[Marital asset additional language AK TE]%%

components.name: 2-Temporary order needed?
components.text: Do you need temporary orders in the meantime?
components.learn: What if we are not in agreement on certain key issues?
components.help: If you and your spouse are not in agreement on certain key issues such as custody or financial support, you may file a "Motion and Affidavit for Pre-Decree Relief," which is used to request every type of available relief in a case where a divorce has not yet been granted.

components.name: 3-Yes to Temporary Orders Needed

components.name: 5-Explanation of Uncontested Divorce option
components.text: Based on your answers, uncontested divorce may be an option for you and your spouse. When you finish the interview, more information on uncontested divorce will be included in your Personalized Plan.

components.name: 5-Filed complaint, did you serve spouse?
components.text: You said that you filed a complaint to start the case. Have you served your spouse?
components.learn: What is service?
components.help: As part of the divorce, your spouse must be properly given a copy of the divorce forms you filed at court so that they know you are starting the divorce process. This is called "serving your spouse."

components.name: 6-Did not serve spouse
components.text:
Proper service is required at the beginning of every divorce action because:

1. it tells your spouse what is going on, and
2. it gives your spouse a change to respond to the court papers.

components.text: Does your spouse live in the same state as you?
